thread.title: Terrorists are building drones - France is destroying them with eagles
thread.title_full: Terrorists are building drones - France is destroying them with eagles

author: Avi Selk
title: Terrorists are building drones - France is destroying them with eagles
text:
Terrorists are building drones - France is destroying them with eagles Avi Selk twitter TWEET More 
Under French military supervision, four golden eagle chicks hatched last year atop drones - born into a world of terror and machines they would be bred to destroy. 
The eagles - named d'Artagnan, Athos, Porthos and Aramis - grew up with their nemeses. They chased drones through green grass that summer, pecking futilely at composite shells . They were rewarded with meat, which they ate off the backs of the drones. David Taylor arrives at Denpasar District Court Play Video Trained eagle swoops on consumer drones Trained eagle swoops on consumer drones 
As the Dutch government looks for ways to counter the undesirable use of consumer drones, the Dutch National Police release a video showcasing a trained bird of prey plucking a drone from the sky. (Dutch National Police) Up Next David Taylor arrives at Denpasar District Court Play Video David Taylor arrives at Denpasar District Court 
Media surrounds David Taylor arrives at Denpasar District Court ahead of his sentencing. Up Next South Sudan officially in famine Play Video South Sudan officially in famine South Sudan officially in famine 
Parts of war-ravaged South Sudan is hit by famine, as government official says nearly half the country's population would lack reliable access to affordable food by July. Up Next Sweden to Trump: When you are in a hole, stop digging Play Video Sweden to Trump: When you are in a hole, ... Sweden to Trump: When you are in a hole, stop digging 
After Donald Trump's apparent reference to a non-existent incident in Sweden raises eyebrows, the US President doubles down on his claim Sweden's immigration policy is "working out just beautifully. NOT!" Up Next Pence brings EU a message of partnership Play Video Pence brings EU a message of partnership Pence brings EU a message of partnership 
US Vice President Mike Pence sought to reassure the European Union in Brussels on Monday that the Trump administration will maintain and develop decades of partnership in trade and security. Up Next 
Key moments from the first month of the 45th President of the US, Donald J. Trump. Up Next China bans North Korean coal Play Video China bans North Korean coal China bans North Korean coal 
China suspends imports of North Korean coal as part of its efforts to implement United Nations sanctions against the country. Up Next British MPs debate Trump's UK state visit Play Video British MPs debate Trump's UK state visit British MPs debate Trump's UK state visit 
Donald Trumpâs impending state visit to the UK causes protests in London and a debate in Parliament after a petition to ban his trip attracted almost two million signatures. More videos Trained eagle swoops on consumer drones 
As the Dutch government looks for ways to counter the undesirable use of consumer drones, the Dutch National Police release a video showcasing a trained bird of prey plucking a drone from the sky. (Dutch National Police) 
When the eagles were ready - this month - d'Artagnan launched screeching from a military control tower across a field, Agence France-Presse reported. 
The bird covered 200 metres in 20 seconds, slamming into a drone, then diving with the wreckage into the tall grass. Related Content French police to hunt operators of mystery drones over Paris 
"The eagles are making good progress," said the French air force's commander of a program that adapts the ancient art of falconry to the threats of unmanned flight. 
Weeks earlier, on the other side of the world, Iraqi soldiers fired their guns wildly into the sky after a small drone dropped a bomb on them. Terrorists have been modifying devices that can be bought in toy stores into weapons and radio-controlled spies, the Associated Press reported. Advertisement 
The French have been concerned since early 2015, when drones flew over the presidential palace and a restricted military site , according to Agence France-Presse. 
No one was harmed. But terrorist attacks later that year, including the November massacre in Paris, inspired military officials to creative prevention. SHARE
